Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project funds the replication and extension of the Biology Scholars Program. The goals are to continue to empower more biologists to be leaders in science education reform; to expand and support an interactive community of biologists committed to scientific teaching and the scholarship of teaching and learning; and through these biologists, to catalyze the network of life science professional societies for the purpose of developing sustained undergraduate education reform. To accomplish these goals, biologists are recruited based on interest, a commitment to changing the way they teach, and a willingness to become catalysts for change at their institution and any biological professional society they belong to. Once selected they are briefed through electronic communication and brought together with their colleagues for an intense face to face workshop experience. They are also provided with expert mentoring until they have reached the goals they have committed to achieving in teaching and leading colleagues at their home institution and through their professional society. Approximately 250 biologists are to be educated and at least 9 professional societies are targeted in this project.

This project is being co-funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

OVERVIEW

Many prominent organizations have expressed the need for science educators, particularly those charged with developing undergraduates, to practice instruction grounded in the scholarship of teaching and learning. In response, the American Society for Microbiology and National Science Foundation sponsored the ASM-NSF Biology Scholars Program (BSP) from 2005 to 2015 to help biologists (i) make evidence-based enhancements to their teaching at the undergraduate level and (ii) work with professional societies to lead science education reform. Designed as a comprehensive professional development initiative, the program achieves its goals through yearlong Assessment, Research, and Transitions Residencies – independent, yet intertwined training experiences that meld online learning with in-person and intensive multiday institutes.

•    The Assessment Residency helps scholars design course goals and assessments aligned with evidence on how people learn. Participants also create and implement evaluations that provide formative and summative feedback. The residency has trained about 90 biologists in five years (Figure 1).
•    The Research Residency helps scholars to (i) deepen their understanding of evidence-based research in biology education learning and (ii) design and implement experiments to assess student learning. The residency has trained about 180 biologists in 11 years (Figure 1).
•    The Transitions Residency helps scholars “transition” from conducting scholarly work in student learning to preparing for publication in peer-reviewed biology and science education venues. Participants learn to organize data, identify relevant literature, and develop writing plans and timelines. The residency has trained more than 30 biologists in seven years (Figure 1).

During their residencies, scholars benefit from foundational learning as well as interactions with and support from BSP peers and leaders. Scholars are encouraged to participate in the annual ASM Conference for Undergraduate Educators (ASMCUE), mentor others, and develop into leaders. After residency completion, scholars join the Biology Scholars Alumni, a group committed to sharing their scholarship in teaching biology.

OUTCOMES

The BSP differs from other professional development programs for biologists in that it helps move them from individual scholarship in student assessment to mentoring and leading colleagues in their departments, institutions, and professional societies. More than 270 biology educators looking to improve their teaching and student learning have received training as peer mentors, community builders, and leaders. Thus, the BSP has evolved from a small faculty development program to a robust, national initiative for scholarly teaching. ASM commissioned an extensive review of the BSP in 2014. Focused on scholars who participated in the program between 2010 and 2014, the study found evidence of three types of program contributions:

1.    BSP supports scholarship and leadership. Scholars have developed more than 200 education-related research projects and have published and presented education research via more than 150 society publications and national conferences (Figure 2). They are sought regionally and nationally to sponsor assessment and curriculum workshops for graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and other faculty on campuses and scientific meetings; lead curriculum committees and reform efforts on campus; and serve in administrative and leadership positions.
